'''''Transcendence''''' is a 2014 American [[science fiction film|science fiction]] [[thriller film]] directed by cinematographer [[Wally Pfister]] in his directorial debut, and written by Jack Paglen. The film stars [[Johnny Depp]], [[Rebecca Hall]], [[Paul Bettany]], [[Kate Mara]], [[Cillian Murphy]], [[Cole Hauser]], and [[Morgan Freeman]]. Pfister's usual collaborator, [[Christopher Nolan]], served as executive producer on the project.
Paglen's screenplay was listed on the 2012 edition of [[The Black List (survey)|The Black List]], a list of popular unproduced screenplays in Hollywood.<ref name="blacklist">{{cite web|url=http://files.blcklst.com/2012_black_list.pdf |title=The Black List 2012 |publisher=The Black List |accessdate=April 5, 2017}}</ref> ''Transcendence'' was a disappointment at the box office, grossing just $103 million against a budget of at least $100 million. The film received mainly negative reviews; it was criticized for its plot structure, characters and dialogue.
==Plot== Dr. Will Caster ([[Johnny Depp]]) is a scientist who researches the nature of [[sapience]], including [[artificial intelligence]]. He and his team work to create a [[Computational theory of mind|sentient computer]]; he predicts that such a computer will create a [[technological singularity]], or in his words "Transcendence". His wife, Evelyn ([[Rebecca Hall]]), is also a scientist and helps him with his work.
Following one of Will's presentations, an [[Neo-Luddism|anti-technology]] terrorist group called "Revolutionary Independence From Technology" (R.I.F.T.) shoots Will with a [[polonium]]-laced bullet and carries out a series of synchronized attacks on A.I. laboratories across the country. Will is given no more than a month to live. In desperation, Evelyn comes up with a plan to [[mind uploading|upload Will's consciousness]] into the [[quantum computer]] that the project has developed. His best friend and fellow researcher, Max Waters ([[Paul Bettany]]), questions the wisdom of this choice, reasoning that the "uploaded" Will would be only an imitation of the real person. Will's consciousness survives his body's death in this technological form and requests to be connected to the Internet to grow in capability and knowledge. Max refuses to have any part of the experiment. Evelyn demands that Max leave and connects the computer intelligence to the [[Internet]] via satellite.
R.I.F.T.'s leader Bree ([[Kate Mara]]) kidnaps Max and eventually persuades him to join the group. The government is also suspicious of what Will's uploaded consciousness will do and plans to use the terrorists to take the blame for the government's actions to stop him.
In his virtual form and with Evelyn's help, Will uses his new-found vast capabilities to build a technological [[utopia]] in a remote desert town called Brightwood, where he spearheads the development of ground-breaking technologies in medicine, energy, biology, and [[nanotechnology]]. Evelyn, however, grows fearful of Will's motives when he displays the ability to remotely connect to and control people's minds after they have been subjected to his [[nano-particle]]s.
[[Federal Bureau of Investigation|FBI]] agent Donald Buchanan ([[Cillian Murphy]]), with the help of government scientist Joseph Tagger ([[Morgan Freeman]]), plans to stop the sentient entity from spreading. As Will has already spread his influence to all the networked computer technology in the world, Max and R.I.F.T. develop a [[computer virus]] with the purpose of deleting Will's [[source code]], destroying him. Evelyn plans to upload the virus by infecting herself and then having Will upload her consciousness. A side effect of the virus would be the destruction of technological civilization. This would also disable the nano-particles, which have spread in the water, through the wind and have already started to eradicate pollution, disease, and human mortality.
When Evelyn goes back to the research center, she is stunned to see Will in a newly created organic body identical to his old one. Will welcomes her but is instantly aware that she is carrying the virus and intends to destroy him. The FBI and the members of R.I.F.T. attack the base with artillery, destroying much of its power supply and fatally wounding Evelyn. When Bree threatens to kill Max unless Will uploads the virus, Will explains that he has only enough power either to heal Evelyn's physical body or upload the virus. Evelyn tells Will that Max should not die because of what they've done, so Will uploads the virus to save Max. As Will dies, he explains to Evelyn that he did what he did for her, as she had pursued science to repair the damage humans had done to the [[ecosystem]]s. In their last moment, he tells Evelyn to think about their garden. The virus kills both Will and Evelyn, and a global technology collapse and blackout ensues.
Five years later, in Will and Evelyn's garden at their old home in Berkeley, Max notices that their sunflowers are the only blooming plants. Upon closer examination, he notices that a drop of water falling from a sunflower petal instantly cleanses a puddle of oil — and realizes that the [[Faraday cage]] around the garden has protected a sample of Will's sentient nano-particles.
The movie ends with a voiceover by Max: "He created this garden for the same reason he did everything: So they could be together."
==Cast== * [[Johnny Depp]] as Will Caster, a scientist researching artificial intelligence. * [[Rebecca Hall]] as Evelyn Caster, Will's wife and a fellow scientist.<ref name="hall" /> * [[Paul Bettany]] as Max Waters, Will's best friend.<ref name="ng" /> * [[Kate Mara]] as Bree, the leader of the Revolutionary Independence From Technology (R.I.F.T.) terrorist organization.<ref name="ng" /> * [[Cillian Murphy]] as Donald Buchanan, an FBI agent.<ref name="casting" /> * [[Cole Hauser]] as Stevens, a military officer.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Kit | first=Borys | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/cole-hauser-joins-johnny-depp-445769 | title=Cole Hauser Joins Johnny Depp in 'Transcendence' | journal=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date=April 24, 2013 }}</ref> * [[Morgan Freeman]] as Joseph Tagger, Will and Evelyn's mentor.<ref name="ng" /> * [[Xander Berkeley]] as Dr. Thomas Casey * [[Clifton Collins, Jr.]] as Martin<ref>{{cite journal | last=Kroll | first=Justin | url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/clifton-collins-rounds-out-cast-of-johnny-depp-pic-transcendence-exclusive-hold-1200379658/ | title=Clifton Collins boards Johnny Depp pic 'Transcendence' | journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=April 17, 2013 }}</ref> * [[Cory Hardrict]] as Joel Edmund, a R.I.F.T. terrorist.<ref name="casting">{{cite journal | last=Kit | first=Borys | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/casting-call-tomorrowland-transcendence-add-524733 | title=Casting Call: 'Tomorrowland', 'Transcendence' Add Actors | journal=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date=May 17, 2013 }}</ref> * [[Josh Stewart]] as Paul, a blind man who is healed by Will's nanomachines. * [[Falk Hentschel]] as Bob, a R.I.F.T. terrorist.
==Production==
===Development=== ''Transcendence'' is [[Wally Pfister]]'s [[List of directorial debuts|directorial debut]]. Jack Paglen wrote the initial screenplay for Pfister to direct,{{#tag:ref|Jack Paglen's screenplay was featured in the 2012 survey of Hollywood's [[The Black List (survey)|The Black List]], a list of most-liked unproduced screenplays.<ref>{{cite news | last=Jagernauth | first=Kevin | url=http://blogs.indiewire.com/theplaylist/black-list-2012-features-biopics-on-hillary-clinton-dr-seuss-transcendence-more-20121217 | title=Black List 2012 Features Biopics On Hillary Clinton & Dr. Seuss, 'Transcendence' & More | work=[[indieWire]] | date=December 17, 2012 | accessdate=May 9, 2013}}</ref>|group = "nb"}} and producer Annie Marter pitched the film to Straight Up Films.<ref name="mcnary">{{cite journal | last=McNary | first=Dave | url=https://variety.com/2012/film/news/nolan-thomas-to-produce-pfister-s-debut-1118055449/ | title=Nolan, Thomas to produce Pfister’s debut | journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=June 13, 2012 }}</ref> The pitch was sold to Straight Up. By March 2012, [[Alcon Entertainment]] acquired the project.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Kit | first=Borys | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/christopher-nolan-wally-pfister-dark-knight-rises-337015 | title=Christopher Nolan to Exec Produce Wally Pfister's Directorial Debut | journal=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date=June 13, 2012 }}</ref> Alcon financed and produced the film; producers from Straight Up and Alcon joined together for the film. In the following June, director [[Christopher Nolan]], for whom Pfister has worked as cinematographer, and Nolan's producing partner [[Emma Thomas]] joined the film as executive producers.<ref name="mcnary" />
===Financing=== The Chinese company [[DMG Entertainment]] entered a partnership with Alcon Entertainment to finance and produce the film. While DMG contributed Chinese elements to ''[[Looper (film)|Looper]]'' and ''[[Iron Man 3]]'', it did not do so for ''Transcendence''.<ref name="makenin">{{cite news | last=Makenin | first=Julie | url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/envelope/cotown/la-et-ct-johnny-depps-transcendence-gets-china-boost-20130711,0,4064104.story | title=Johnny Depp's 'Transcendence' gets China boost | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=July 11, 2013 }}</ref>
===Casting=== By October 2012, actor [[Johnny Depp]] entered negotiations to star in ''Transcendence''.<ref>{{cite journal | last=Kroll | first=Justin | url=https://variety.com/2012/film/news/johnny-depp-in-talks-for-pfister-s-transcendence-1118061189/ | title=Johnny Depp in talks for Pfister's 'Transcendence' | journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=October 24, 2012 }}</ref> ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]'' said Depp would have "a mammoth payday" with a salary of {{nowrap|$20 million}} versus 15 percent of the film's gross. Pfister met with [[Noomi Rapace]] for the film's female lead role and also met with [[James McAvoy]] and [[Tobey Maguire]] for the other male lead role. The director offered a supporting role to [[Christoph Waltz]].<ref>{{cite journal | last1=Siegel | first1=Tatiana | last2=Kit | first2=Borys | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/news/johnny-depp-talks-transcendence-wally-382289 | title=Johnny Depp in Negotiations to Star in 'Transcendence' for Alcon | journal=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date=October 24, 2012 }}</ref> In March 2013, [[Rebecca Hall]] was cast as the female lead.<ref name="hall">{{cite journal | last=Kit | first=Borys | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/rebecca-hall-joins-johnny-depp-425932 | title=Rebecca Hall Joins Johnny Depp in 'Transcendence' | journal=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date=March 4, 2013 }}</ref> By the following April, actors [[Paul Bettany]], [[Kate Mara]], and [[Morgan Freeman]] joined the main cast.<ref name="ng">{{cite journal | last=Ng | first=Philiana | url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/heat-vision/morgan-freeman-joins-transcendence-437871 | title=Morgan Freeman Joins Johnny Depp in 'Transcendence' | journal=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] | date=April 11, 2013 }}</ref>
===Filming=== Continuing his advocacy for the use of [[film stock]] over [[digital cinematography]], Pfister chose to shoot the film in the [[anamorphic format]] on [[35 mm film]].<ref name="35mm">{{cite journal | url=http://adnanxkhan.com/wally-pfister-to-shoot-transcendence-on-35mm-film-with-mystery-dp/ | title=Wally Pfister slams digital; will shoot TRANSCENDENCE on 35mm film with mystery DP | journal=ADNAN XKHAN | date=November 16, 2012 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140420072745/http://adnanxkhan.com/wally-pfister-to-shoot-transcendence-on-35mm-film-with-mystery-dp/ | archivedate=April 20, 2014 | df=mdy-all }}</ref> Filming officially began in June 2013,<ref>{{cite journal | last=Coonan | first=Clifford | url=https://variety.com/2013/film/news/chinas-dmg-boards-johnny-depps-transcendence-1200561398/ | title=China's DMG Boards Johnny Depp's 'Transcendence' | journal=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]] | date=July 11, 2013 }}</ref> and took place over a period of 62 days.<ref>{{cite web |title=Mark Kermode Talks to Wally Pfister |date= April 8, 2014 |url=http://moviecitynews.com/2014/04/mark-kermode-talks-to-wally-pfister-about-transcendence-and-his-early-erotic-thrillers-650/ |publisher=MovieCityNews |accessdate=April 9, 2014}}</ref> The majority of the movie was filmed in a variety of locations throughout [[Albuquerque]], New Mexico. The fictional town of Brightwood was created in downtown [[Belen, New Mexico|Belen]], New Mexico. The film went through a traditional [[Photochemistry|photochemical]] finish instead of a [[digital intermediate]].<ref name="kodak">{{cite web |title=OnFilm Interview: Jess Hall, BSC |date= December 11, 2013 |url=http://motion.kodak.com/motion/Publications/InCamera/OnFilm_Interview_Jess_Hall_BSC.htm |publisher=[[Eastman Kodak|Kodak]] |accessdate=January 3, 2014}}</ref> In addition to film, a digital master was completed in 4K resolution, and the film was additionally released in [[IMAX]] film format. ''Transcendence'' was also scheduled for a 3D release in China.<ref>{{cite web |title=NAB: Wally Pfister on Turning Johnny Depp Into a Hologram For 'Transcendence |date= April 9, 2014 |url=http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/behind-screen/nab-wally-pfister-turning-johnny-694911 |work=[[The Hollywood Reporter]] |accessdate=April 10, 2014}}</ref>
===Music=== The musical score for the film composed by [[Mychael Danna]] was released on April 15, through WaterTower Music. A CD format of the score was released through Amazon.com.
==Release== ''Transcendence'' was released in theaters on April 18, 2014. It was originally scheduled for April 25, 2014.<ref>{{cite news | author=Staff | url=http://www.deadline.com/2013/04/adam-sandler-drew-barrymore-movie-blended-release-date-may-23-2014/ | title=Warner Bros Dates Adam Sandler-Drew Barrymore Pic 'Blended', Shifts 'Transcendence' | work=[[Deadline Hollywood]] | date=April 24, 2013 | accessdate=May 9, 2013}}</ref>
[[Warner Bros.]] distributed the film in the United States and Canada. [[Summit Entertainment]] (through [[Lions Gate Entertainment|Lionsgate]]) is distributing it in other territories, except for China, Italy, Hong Kong, Austria, United Kingdom, Australia, Ireland, New Zealand and Germany.<ref>{{cite news | last=Foreman | first=Liza | url=https://movies.yahoo.com/news/transcendence-revealed-johnny-depp-play-supercomputer-exclusive-223205796.html | title='Transcendence' Revealed: Johnny Depp to Play Supercomputer | work=The Wrap | publisher=[[Yahoo!]] | date=December 12, 2012 | accessdate=May 9, 2013}}</ref> DMG Entertainment, who collaborated with Alcon Entertainment to finance and develop ''Transcendence'', distributed the film in China.<ref name="makenin" /> The Chinese version includes a 3D and IMAX 3D release, funded by DMG, which is done in post-production.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cinemablend.com/new/Johnny-Depp-Transcendence-3D-China-42221.html |title=Johnny Depp's Transcendence Will Be In 3D, But Only In China |publisher=CinemaBlend.com |date=2014-03-24 |accessdate=July 20, 2014}}</ref>
===Home media=== ''Transcendence'' was released on Blu-ray and DVD on July 22, 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.blu-ray.com/news/?id=14124 |title=Transcendence Blu-ray |publisher=Blu-ray.com |date= |accessdate=July 20, 2014}}</ref>
==Reception==
===Box office=== ''Transcendence'' grossed $23 million in North America and $80 million in other territories for a worldwide total of $103 million.<ref name="mojo" />
On the film's opening weekend, the film grossed $4,813,369 on Friday, $3,820,074 on Saturday and $2,252,943 on Sunday in North America, for a weekend gross of $10,886,386, playing in 3,455 theaters with an average of $3,151 and ranking #4.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=daily&id=transcendence.htm |title=Transcendence – April 2014 |work=Box Office Mojo |accessdate=April 26, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | url=http://boxofficemojo.com/news/?id=3825&p=.htm | title=Weekend Report: 'Captain' Three-peats, 'Heaven' Rises Over Easter Weekend | publisher=IMDB | work=boxofficemojo.com | accessdate=January 22, 2015}}</ref>
The biggest other markets were China, France and South Korea, where the film grossed $20.2 million, $6.45 million and $5.3 million respectively.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.boxofficemojo.com/movies/?page=intl&id=transcendence.htm|title=Transcendence Foreign By country |work= [[Box Office Mojo]] |accessdate=June 12, 2014}}</ref>
===Critical reception=== Publications such as ''[[The Guardian]]'', ''[[Forbes]]'' and ''[[International Business Times]]'' considered the film to be largely a critical failure,<ref name="The Guardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/film/2014/apr/18/transcendence-johnny-depp-2014s-most-unexpected-turkey-film|title=The Johnny Depp Problem|publisher=''[[The Guardian]]''|date=18 April 2014|accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/dorothypomerantz/2014/04/18/the-johnny-depp-problem/ |title=The Johnny Depp Problem|publisher=''[[Forbes]]''|date=18 April 2014|accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://au.ibtimes.com/articles/549846/20140428/transcendence-johnny-depp-critics-negative-film.htm|title='Transcendence' Movie Receives Early Negative Feedback from Film Critics?|publisher= ''[[International Business Times]]'' |date=28 April 2014|accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> with ''The Guardian'' stating that the reviews were "almost universally damning" and referring to the film as "one of 2014's bigger critical turkeys".<ref name="The Guardian"/> Film critic [[Mark Kermode]] said that the film got a "critical kicking" in the UK, much as it did in the US.<ref>{{cite web|author=Kermode, Mark |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/blogs/markkermode/posts/In-Defence-Of-Transcendence?sortBy=RatingValue&sortOrder=Descending|title=In Defence Of Transcendence|publisher=BBC|date=29 April 2014|accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> However, a number of sources considered the film to have received a mixed rather than a primarily negative reception.<ref>{{cite web|title=Insomniac Theater: 'Transcendence' and 'Heaven is for Real' Open|url=http://abcnews.go.com/WNN/video/insomniac-theater-transcendence-heaven-real-open-23375471|publisher=[[ABC News]]|accessdate=June 23, 2014|date=April 18, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Lang|first1=Brent|title='Transcendence' Reviews: Is the Johnny Depp Thriller Trippy or Tedious?|url=https://movies.yahoo.com/news/transcendence-reviews-johnny-depp-thriller-trippy-tedious-151700003.html|publisher=[[Yahoo! Movies]]|accessdate=June 23, 2014|date=April 16, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Review: Is the Heady Johnny Depp Tech Thriller 'Transcendence' Ahead of Its Time?|url=http://www.indiewire.com/article/review-is-the-heady-johnny-depp-tech-thriller-transcendence-ahead-of-its-time|publisher=[[IndieWire]]|accessdate=June 23, 2014|date=April 15, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title='Transcendence' Reviews: Is the Johnny Depp Thriller Trippy or Tedious?|url=http://www.thewrap.com/transcendence-reviews-johnny-depp-thriller-trippy-tedious/|publisher=[[The Wrap]]|accessdate=June 23, 2014|date=April 16, 2014}}</ref>
Film review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]] gives the film a rating of 20%, based on 211 reviews, with an average rating of 4.6/10. The site's critical consensus reads, "In his directorial debut, ace cinematographer Wally Pfister remains a distinctive visual stylist, but ''Transcendence''{{'}}s thought-provoking themes exceed the movie's narrative grasp."<ref name="rt">{{cite web | url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/transcendence_2014/ | title=Transcendence | work=[[Rotten Tomatoes]] | accessdate=June 14, 2015}}</ref> On [[Metacritic]], the film has a score of 42 out of 100, based on 45 critics, indicating "mixed or average reviews".<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.metacritic.com/movie/transcendence | title=Transcendence Reviews | work=[[Metacritic]] | accessdate=April 22, 2014}}</ref>
Criticism was aimed largely at the film's poor logic and storytelling.<ref>{{cite news | last=Ryan | first=Tim | url=https://blogs.wsj.com/speakeasy/2014/04/18/review-revue-transcendence-heaven-is-for-real-bears-a-haunted-house-2/ | title=Review Revue: 'Transcendence,' 'Heaven Is for Real,' 'Bears,' 'A Haunted House 2' | work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=April 18, 2014 | accessdate=April 19, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite news | last=Gettell | first=Oliver | url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-transcendence-johnny-depp-movie-reviews-critics-20140418,0,1613607.story | title='Transcendence': Techno-thriller doesn't compute, critics say | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | date=April 18, 2014 | accessdate=April 18, 2014}}</ref> [[Michael Atkinson (writer)|Michael Atkinson]] of ''[[Sight & Sound]]'' identified "vast plot holes and superhuman leaps of logic", writing that "[f]or all its gloss, hipster pretensions, plot craters and sometimes risible attempts at action, ''Transcendence'' traffics in large, troublesome ideas about Right Now and What’s Ahead, even if the film itself is far too timid and compromised to do those hairy questions justice".<ref>{{cite web|author=Atkinson, Michael|url=http://www.bfi.org.uk/news-opinion/sight-sound-magazine/reviews-recommendations/review-transcendence|title=Transcendence|publisher=British Film Institute|date=9 May 2014|accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> William Thomas of ''[[Empire Magazine|Empire]]'' believed that the cast and director had been "wasted on a B-Movie script with pretensions of prescience", dismissing the film as a "banal sci-fi slog"; he awarded it a 2 out of 5 star "poor" rating.<ref>{{cite web|author=Thomas, William|url=http://www.empireonline.com/reviews/reviewcomplete.asp?FID=138431|title=Transcendence|publisher=''[[Empire Magazine|Empire]]'' |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> [[David Denby]] of ''[[The New Yorker]]'' considered the film to be "rhythmless and shapeless" with "some very cheesy and even amateurish fighting".<ref>{{cite web|author=Denby, David|url=http://www.newyorker.com/arts/reviews/film/transcendence_pfister|title=Transcendence|work=[[The New Yorker]] |accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> Nigel Floyd of [[Film4]] concluded that it was "[a]n ambitious, old fashioned, ideas-driven science fiction film that is never as mind-expanding as its futuristic images and topical, dystopian ideas seem to promise".<ref>{{cite web|author=Floyd, Nigel|url=http://www.film4.com/reviews/2014/transcendence|title=Transcendence|publisher=[[Film4]]|accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> Artificial intelligence expert [[Barney Pell]] criticized the film's depiction of [[3D printing]], saying that the self-organizing smart particles in the film "could quite possibly violate laws of physics."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.recode.net/2014/5/1/11626334/transcending-artificial-intelligence-part-1|title=Transcending Artificial Intelligence: Part 1|publisher=Recode|author=Barney Pell|date=1 May 2014}}</ref>
Contrary to the many less than flattering reviews that the film received, [[Richard Roeper]] of the ''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]'' lauded the film and awarded it four stars, calling it a "bold, beautiful flight of futuristic speculation" and " a stunning piece of work".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.suntimes.com/entertainment/movies/26871091-421/transcendence-johnny-depp-in-a-bold-beautiful-flight-of-futuristic-speculation.html#.U8KYWbG8OYc|title=‘Transcendence’: Johnny Depp in a bold, beautiful flight of futuristic speculation |publisher=''[[Chicago Sun-Times]]''|date=19 May 2014|accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> [[Kenneth Turan]] of the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' was also positive towards the film, praising the quality of the cast and intelligence of the script.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/movies/moviesnow/la-et-mn-transcendence-review20140418-story.html#page=1|title=Review: 'Transcendence' rises above the sci-fi genre |publisher=''[[The Los Angeles Times]]''|date=17 April 2014|accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> Some sources like ''[[The Independent]]'' thought that the negative reviews reported for the film were harsh and that the film was "stylish and entertaining", treading a "fairly well-judged path between paranoia and technological utopianism".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/reviews/transcendence-film-review-johnny-depps-scifi-transcends-bad-reviews-9290996.html|title=Transcendence, film review: Johnny Depp's sci-fi transcends bad reviews |publisher=''[[The Independent]]'' |date=26 April 2014|accessdate=July 13, 2014}}</ref> AI researcher [[Stuart J. Russell|Stuart Russell]] claims that despite particular technical aspects of the movie being "a non-starter", the basic premise of [[superhuman AI]] is quite possible, and that "AI researchers must, like nuclear physicists and genetic engineers before them, take seriously the possibility that their research might actually succeed and do their utmost to ensure that their work benefits rather than endangers their own species."<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/stuart-russell/ai-transcendence_b_5235364.html? | title = Transcendence: An AI Researcher Enjoys Watching His Own Execution | work=[[Huffington Post]] | accessdate=October 2, 2016}}</ref>
Months after the film's release, [[RogerEbert.com]] reviewer Scout Tafoya defended the film as an under-appreciated great work, claiming its failure was partially due to the marketing of the film as a thriller instead of a "heartbreaking" human drama.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rogerebert.com/mzs/the-unloved-part-9-transcendence|title=The Unloved, Part 9: "Transcendence" - MZS - Roger Ebert|first=Scout|last=Tafoya|publisher=}}</ref>

[[File:Trojan wavepacket hue.gif|thumb|right|Trojan wavepacket evolution animation]] [[File:Z80Trojan.gif|thumb|right|Classical simulation of the Trojan wavepacket on 1982 home [[ZX Spectrum]] microcomputer. The packet is approximated by the ensemble of points initially randomly localized within the peek of a Gaussian and moving according to the [[Newton%27s_laws_of_motion|Newton equations]]. The ensemble stays localized. For the comparison the second simulation follows when the strength of the circularly polarized electric (rotating) field is equal to zero and the packet (points) fully spreads around the circle.]] A '''trojan wave packet''' is a [[wave packet]] that is nonstationary and nonspreading. It is part of an artificially created system that consists of a [[atomic nucleus|nucleus]] and one or more electron wave packets, and that is highly excited under a continuous electromagnetic field.
The strong, polarized [[electromagnetic field]], holds or "traps" each electron wave packet in an intentionally selected orbit (energy shell).<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.cft.edu.pl/~birula/publ/RadTroj.pdf|doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.56.3623|title=Radiative decay of Trojan wave packets|date=1997|author=Bialynicka-Birula, Zofia|journal=Physical Review A|volume=56|pages=3623|last2=Bialynicki-Birula|first2=Iwo|bibcode = 1997PhRvA..56.3623B|issue=5 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1103/PhysRevA.53.1715|title=Trojan wave packets: Mathieu theory and generation from circular states|date=1996|author=Kalinski, Maciej|journal=Physical Review A|volume=53|pages=1715–1724|pmid=9913064|last2=Eberly|first2=JH|issue=3 |bibcode = 1996PhRvA..53.1715K }}</ref> They derive their names from the [[Trojan (astronomy)|trojan asteroid]]s in the Sun–Jupiter system.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Kochański |first=Piotr |last2=Bialynicka-Birula |first2=Zofia |last3=Bialynicki-Birula |first3=Iwo |date=2000 |title=Squeezing of electromagnetic field in a cavity by electrons in Trojan states |journal= Physical Review A|volume= 63|issue= |page=1 |url= |id= |postscript=<!--None--> |arxiv=quant-ph/0007033v1|bibcode = 2001PhRvA..63a3811K |doi = 10.1103/PhysRevA.63.013811 }}</ref> Trojan asteroids orbit around the Sun in [[Jupiter]]'s orbit at its [[Lagrangian point|Lagrangian equilibrium point]]s L4 and L5, where they are phase-locked and protected from collision with each other, and this phenomenon is analogous to the way the wave packet is held together.
==Concepts and research== The concept of the Trojan wave packet is derived from a flourishing area of physics which manipulates atoms and ions at the atomic level creating [[ion traps]]. Ion traps allow the manipulation of atoms and are used to create new states of matter including [[ionic liquid]]s, [[Wigner crystal]]s and [[Bose–Einstein condensate]]s.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Andrews | first = M. R. | author2 = C. G. Townsend | author3 = H.-J. Miesner | author4 = D. S. Durfee | author5 = D. M. Kurn | author6 = W. Ketterle | title = Observation of Interference Between Two Bose Condensates | journal = Science | volume = 275 | issue = 5300 | pages = 637–641 | date = 1997| doi = 10.1126/science.275.5300.637 | pmid =9005843}}</ref> This ability to manipulate the quantum properties directly is key to the real life development of applicable [[Nanotechnology|nanodevices]] such as [[quantum dots]] and microchip traps. In 2004 it was shown that it is possible to create a trap which is actually a single atom. Within the atom, the behavior of an electron can be manipulated.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Maeda, H. |author2=Gallagher, T. F. |lastauthoramp=yes | title = Nondispersing Wave Packets | journal = Phys. Rev. Lett. |volume=92|date=2004|page=133004 | doi = 10.1103/PhysRevLett.92.133004 | bibcode=2004PhRvL..92m3004M | issue = 13}}</ref>
During experiments in 2004 using lithium atoms in an excited state, researchers were able to localize an electron in a classical orbit for 15,000 orbits (900 ns). It was neither spreading nor dispersing. This "classical atom" was synthesized by "tethering" the electron using a microwave field to which its motion is phase locked. The phase lock of the electrons in this unique atomic system is, as mentioned above, analogous to the phase locked asteroids of Jupiter's orbit.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Maeda | first = H.|author2=D. V. L. Norum |author3=T. F. Gallagher | title = Microwave Manipulation of an Atomic Electron in a Classical Orbit | journal = Science| volume = 307| issue = 5716 | pages = 1757–1760 | date = 2005| doi = 10.1126/science.1108470 | pmid = 15705805|bibcode = 2005Sci...307.1757M }}Originally published in Science Express on 10 February 2005</ref>
The techniques explored in this experiment are a solution to a problem that dates back to 1926. Physicists at that time realized that any initially localized wave packet will inevitably spread around the orbit of the electrons. Physicist noticed that "the wave equation is dispersive for the atomic Coulomb potential." In the 1980s several groups of researchers proved this to be true. The wave packets spread all the way around the orbits and coherently interfered with themselves. Recently the real world innovation realized with experiments such as Trojan wave packets, is localizing the wave packets, i.e., with no dispersion. Applying a polarized circular EM field, at microwave frequencies, synchronized with an electron wave packet, intentionally keeps the electron wave packets in a Lagrange type orbit.<ref>{{cite journal | last = Stroud | first = C. R. Jr.| volume = 2 | issue = 19 | title = An astronomical solution to an old quantum problem | doi = 10.1103/Physics.2.19 | date = 2009 | journal = Physics | pages = 19|bibcode = 2009PhyOJ...2...19S }}</ref><ref>{{cite book | last = Murray | first = C. D. |author2=Dermot, S. F. | title = Solar System Dynamics | publisher = Cambridge University Press | date = 2000 | location = Cambridge, United Kingdom | pages = | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=aU6vcy5L8GAC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Solar+System+Dynamics,++murray|isbn = 978-0-521-57597-3}}</ref> The Trojan wave packet experiments built on previous work with lithium atoms in an excited state. These are atoms, which respond sensitively to electric and magnetic fields, have decay periods that are relatively prolonged, and electrons, which for all intents and purposes actually operate in classical orbits. The sensitivity to electric and magnetic fields is important because this allows control and response by the polarized microwave field.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sunysb.edu/metcalf/rydbergprint.htm |title=Rydberg Atom Optics |accessdate=2008-07-30 |author=Metcalf Research Group |date=2004-11-08 |publisher=Stoney Brook University |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050826121501/http://www.sunysb.edu/metcalf/rydbergprint.htm |archivedate=August 26, 2005 }}</ref>
===Beyond single electron wave packets===
[[Image:Wave packet (dispersion).gif|right|thumb|200px|In physics, a '''[[wave packet]]''' is a short "burst" or "envelope" of wave action that travels as a unit. A wave packet can be analyzed into, or can be synthesized from, an infinite set of component [[sinusoidal wave]]s of different [[wavenumber]]s, with phases and amplitudes such that they interfere constructively only over a small region of space, and destructively elsewhere.<ref> {{cite book | title = Quantum Physics: An Introduction | author = Joy Manners | publisher = CRC Press | date = 2000 | isbn = 978-0-7503-0720-8 | pages = 53–56 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=LkDQV7PNJOMC&pg=PA54&dq=wave-packet+wavelengths}}</ref>]]
The next logical step is to attempt to move from single electron wave packets to more than one electron [[wave packet]]. This had already been accomplished in [[barium]] atoms, with two electron wave packets. These two were localized. However, eventually, these created [[Dispersion (materials science)|dispersion]] after colliding near the nucleus. Another technique employed a nondispersive pair of electrons, but one of these had to have a localized orbit close to the nucleus. The nondispersive two-electron Trojan wave packets demonstration changes all that. These are the next step analogue of the one electron Trojan wave packets - and designed for excited helium atoms.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.85.2356|title=Localization in Artificial Disorder: Two Coupled Quantum Dots|date=2000|author=Brodsky, M.|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=85|pages=2356–9|pmid=10978009|last2=Zhitenev|first2=NB|last3=Ashoori|first3=RC|last4=Pfeiffer|first4=LN|last5=West|first5=KW|issue=11|bibcode=2000PhRvL..85.2356B|arxiv = cond-mat/0001455 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.82.161|title=Observation of Quantum Fluctuations of Charge on a Quantum Dot|date=1999|author=Berman, D.|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=82|pages=161|last2=Zhitenev|first2=N.|last3=Ashoori|first3=R.|last4=Shayegan|first4=M.|bibcode=1999PhRvL..82..161B|arxiv = cond-mat/9803373 }}</ref>
As of July 2005, atoms with coherent, stable two-electron, nondispersing wave packets had been created. These are excited helium-like atoms, or [[quantum dot]] helium (in [[Solid-state physics|solid-state]] applications), and are atomic (quantum) analogues to the [[three body problem]] of Newton's [[classical physics]], which includes today's [[astrophysics]]. In tandem, circularly [[Polarization (waves)|polarized]] electromagnetic and magnetic fields stabilize the two electron configuration in the [[helium atom]] or the quantum dot helium (with impurity center). The stability is maintained over a broad [[Electromagnetic spectrum|spectrum]], and because of this, the configuration of two electron wave packets is considered to be truly nondispersive. For example, with the quantum dot helium, configured for confining electrons in two spatial dimensions, there now exists a variety of trojan wave packet configurations with two electrons , and as of 2005, only one in three dimensions.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.95.103001|title=Nondispersive Two-Electron Wave Packets in a Helium Atom|date=2005|author=Kalinski, Matt|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=95|pages=103001|pmid=16196925|last2=Hansen|first2=Loren|last3=David|first3=Farrelly|issue=10|bibcode=2005PhRvL..95j3001K}}</ref> In 2012 an essential experimental step was undertaken not only generating but locking the Trojan wavepackets on adiabatically changed frequency and expanding the atoms as once predicted by Kalinski and [[Joseph H. Eberly|Eberly]].<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1364/OE.1.000216|title=Guiding electron orbits with chirped light|date=1997|author=Kalinski, M.|journal=Optics Express|volume=1|pages=216|pmid=|last2=Eberly|first2=J.|issue=7|bibcode=1997OExpr...1..216K}}</ref> It will allow to create two electron [[Irving Langmuir|Langmuir]] Trojan wave packets in Helium by the sequential excitation in adiabatic Stark field able to produce the circular one-electron aureola over {{chem|He|+}} first and then put the second electron in similar state.<ref>{{cite journal|doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.108.043001|title=Creating and Transporting Trojan Wave Packets|date=2012|author=Wyker, B.|journal=Physical Review Letters|volume=108|pages=043001|pmid= 22400833|last2=Ye|first2=S.|last3=Dunning|first3=F. B.|last4=Yoshida|first4=S.|last5=Reinhold|first5=C.O.|last6=Burgdörfer|first6=J.|issue=4|bibcode=2012PhRvL.108d3001W|url=https://scholarship.rice.edu/bitstream/1911/70609/1/Creating%20and%20Transporting%20TrojanWave%20Packets.pdf}}</ref>

<!-- Please leave this line alone! --> Women have been active participants in the development of [[radio]] (initially called "[[wireless]]") communications since its beginning. The age of [[radio communication]] began with the development of [[wireless telegraphy]] around 1900, in which [[Morse code]] could be transmitted over large distances using simple [[spark gap]] or [[carbon arc]] transmitting equipment, and various types of detectors for reception. [[Guglielmo Marconi]] achieved international fame in 1901 when he succeeded in sending a simple message in Morse code - the letter "s" - across the Atlantic from [[Cornwall]] in [[England]] to [[Newfoundland (island)|Newfoundland]].
==Women as wireless operators== Women had worked as [[telegraph]] operators since the late 1840s, and it was not long before women telegraphers began to work as wireless operators as well. In early 1901, the announcement of the inauguration of a Hawaiian inter-island communications system noted that four of the fourteen operators were women.<ref>[http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85047165/1901-02-02/ed-1/seq-1/ "Marconi's System Finally a Success"], ''Honolulu Republican'', February 2, 1901, p. 1.</ref> In 1906, Anna Nevins, who had worked as a telegrapher for [[Western Union]], began work as a wireless operator for [[Lee de Forest]]'s station "NY", located at 42 Broadway in [[New York City]]. She was later employed as a wireless operator at the [[Waldorf-Astoria Hotel]] in New York City.<ref>Moreau, Louise R., "The Feminine Touch in Telecommunications." ''The A.W.A. Review,'' Volume 4, 1989, pp. 79-80.</ref>
==Early female shipboard operators== One of the earliest applications of wireless telegraphy was enabling communication between ships at sea and land stations. While early ships' operators were mostly male, some women entered the field as well. The primary requirement was a knowledge of Morse code and equipment operation, which many female telegraph operators possessed. Perhaps the earliest woman to operate on shipboard was Medora Olive Newell, an experienced telegrapher who was a passenger on the [[Cunard]] liner Slavonia in 1904, when Hungarian members of the [[Hague]] Peace Commission wished to send a birthday greeting to [[Emperor Franz Josef]] of [[Austria-Hungary]]. Medora Olive Newell (1872 - December 31, 1946) began work as a telegraph operator in Durango, [[Iowa]], in 1886 at the age of fourteen. In 1897, she moved to [[Chicago]] and became a commercial operator for the Postal Telegraph Company.<ref>Obituary for Medora O. Newell, ''Long Beach Independent'', Long Beach, CA, January 1, 1947.</ref> [[File:Medora Olive Newell.jpg|thumb|right|Medora Olive Newell, Early Wireless Telegrapher. Source: ''Chicago Daily Tribune, '', February 13, 1907.]] Newell’s first-class operator pay enabled her to live a fairly affluent lifestyle; as ''Telegraph Age'' reported in 1909, “Miss Newell has been in the habit of spending her vacations abroad, and has always made these trips the occasion for investigating telegraph and railway management and operation in European countries.”<ref>''Telegraph Age'', June 1, 1909, p. 396.</ref> On her return voyage from Europe in 1904, she found herself aboard the Cunard liner Slavonia together with members of the Hague Peace Commission, who were on their way to the United States to persuade President [[Theodore Roosevelt]] to call another international conference to continue the work begun at the Hague in 1899. The Hungarian members of the delegation wished to send a birthday greeting to Emperor Franz Josef of Austria-Hungary by wireless, but the ship’s wireless operator was unable to send the message. Newell, who, according to ''Telegraph Age'', “had a good working knowledge of wireless,” took her place at the key and soon had successfully transmitted the greeting. The grateful delegates thanked her for her assistance, and the secretary of the Hungarian parliament invited her to visit Hungary as the guest of the nation.<ref>Jepsen, ''My Sisters Telegraphic'', p. 69.</ref>
In the United States, the [[Wireless Ship Act of 1910]] required US ships to be equipped with wireless equipment for the first time, and to have an operator on board who was capable of sending and receiving messages. The first woman to be officially employed as a shipboard wireless operator was Graynella Packer, a telegrapher from [[Jacksonville, Florida]], who was employed as a wireless operator for the [[United Wireless Telegraph Company]] aboard the steamship Mohawk from November 1910 to April 1911.<ref name="feminine">{{cite magazine | title=The Feminine Wireless Amateur | work= The Electrical Experimenter| date=October 1916 | pages= 396–7, 452 | url=https://archive.org/details/electricalexperi04gern/page/396/mode/1up | accessdate= 2018-11-17 }}</ref> Packer started practicing telegraphy in order to send messages in code to her school friends as a young girl. She eventually took on telegraphy as a career because her eyes were not strong and 'handling a key is no strain on the sight'.<ref>(January 3, 1911). [http://oceanlinersblog.org/wp-content/uploads/2011/09/St.-Petersburg-Evening-Independent-3-jan-1911.png Girl Wireless Operator]. Publisher: St. Petersburg (Florida) Evening Independent</ref> She became manager of the Postal Telegraph office in Sanford, Florida, before hiring onto the Mohawk as the first woman wireless operator to serve aboard a steamship in a commercial capacity. After operating in full charge of the wireless, she eventually moved on to become an elected member of the Oklahoma State Bar Association from Oklahoma City in 1922.<ref>(1992)[https://books.google.com/books?id=wdg8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA227&dq=graynella+packer&lr=&as_brr=1#v=onepage&q=graynella%20packer&f=false Proceedings of the Annual Meetings of the Oklahoma State Bar]. Page 227. Publisher: Oklahoma State Bar Association</ref> [[File:Graynella packer.jpg|thumb|right|Graynella Packer, Wireless Operator, 1910. Source: ''The Electrical Experimenter'', October 1916.]] The [[Radio Act of 1912]] required radio operators in the U.S. to be licensed for the first time. The first woman to be licensed as a shipboard operator was Mabelle Kelso, who passed the operator's examination and received her operating license in January 1912.<ref name="operators">{{cite web | title= YL Amateur Radio Operators: 'Their Struggles and Achievements' | author= Elizabeth (VE7TLK/VA7TK)|work=qsl.net|date=2008| url= http://www.qsl.net/ylradio/archives/YLstor/images/YLSlideShow7.pdf | accessdate= 2018-11-17 }}</ref> Mabelle Kelso was a native of [[Seattle, Washington]], and had been previously employed as a stenographer. After passing a [[U.S. Navy Department]] examination, she was hired by the United Wireless Telegraph Company and assigned a position as an operator on board the SS Mariposa, a steamship which travelled between Seattle and Alaska. Her appointment as shipboard operator generated some opposition from members of Congress who wished to bar women from holding such positions on seagoing ships; however, she received support from the Pacific Coast Wireless Inspector of United Wireless, who stated that "he knew of no law which would bar Miss Kelso from her position."<ref>"Miss Kelso of Seattle, Only Woman to Hold License as Wireless Operator," ''Atlanta Constitution'', July 7, 1912.</ref><ref>"May Flash Law On Wireless Girl," ''Oakland Tribune'', Oakland, California, July 25, 1912.</ref> By 1913, over 30 women had been licensed as shipboard operators.<ref>Moreau, "The Feminine Touch in Telecommunications," p. 80.</ref>
==Women as radio amateurs== [[Amateur radio]] became a popular hobby in the early years of the twentieth century, and many hobbyists built their own transmitting and receiving equipment. Some of the earliest women radio amateurs, called "YLs," were Mrs. M.J. Glass of [[San Jose, California]], who operated as station FNFN in 1910, and Olive Heartburg, who operated as station OHK in [[New York City]] in the same year.<ref>Moreau, "The Feminine Touch in Telecommunications," p. 82.</ref> M.S. Colville, of Bowmanville, [[Ontario]], who began to operate as XDD in 1914, was one of the earliest Canadian YLs.<ref name="operators"/>
The [[Radio Act of 1912]] also required radio amateurs to be licensed. [[Gladys Kathleen Parkin]] (September 27, 1901 - August 3, 1990)<ref>{{cite web | title= California Death Index, 1940 - 1997 | work= Ancestry.com | url= http://vitals.rootsweb.ancestry.com/ca/death/search.cgi | accessdate= 2012-01-27 }}</ref> was one of the earliest women to obtain a government issued license. In 1916, while a fifteen-year-old high school student at the Dominican College in [[San Rafael, California]], she obtained a first class commercial radio operators' license with the call sign 6SO. [[File:gladys kathleen parkin.jpg|thumb|right|[[Gladys Kathleen Parkin]], 1916. Source: ''The [[Electrical Experimenter]]'', October 1916.]]
Parkin was quoted in an article titled "The Feminine Wireless Amateur," which appeared in the October 1916 issue of ''The Electrical Experimenter'':
"With reference to my ideas about the wireless profession as a vocation or worthwhile hobby for women, I think wireless telegraphy is a most fascinating study, and one which could very easily be taken up by girls, as it is a great deal more interesting than the telephone and telegraph work, in which so many girls are now employed. I am only fifteen, and I learned the code several years ago, by practising a few minutes each day on a buzzer. I studied a good deal and I found it quite easy to obtain my first grade commercial government license, last April. It seems to me that every one should at least know the code, as cases might easily arise of a ship in distress, where the operators might be incapacitated, and a knowledge of the code might be the means of saving the ship and the lives of the passengers. But the interest in wireless does not end in the knowledge of the code. You can gradually learn to make all your own instruments, as I have done with my 1/4 kilowatt set. There is always more ahead of you, as wireless telegraphy is still in its infancy."<ref name="feminine"/> Use of the term "YL" to refer to female radio amateurs was formally adopted by the [[American Radio Relay League]] in 1920.
==World War I and women as radio operators== [[File:ww1 wireless women.jpg|thumb|right|Naval reservists training as wireless operators, 1916. Source: ''The Electrical Experimenter'', October 1916.]] As the U.S. prepared to enter [[World War I]], the Navy Department began a program to train women as radio operators who could be called into action in the event of war. The Girls' Division of the United States Junior Naval Reserve established training camps at the Martha Washington Post, in Edgewater, New Jersey, and the Betsy Ross Post, at Bay Ridge, [[Brooklyn]], where young women were trained to become wireless operators.<ref name="feminine"/>
In January 1917, the [[National League for Women's Service]] (NLWS) was created from the Woman’s Department of the National Civic Federation readiness and relief activities and modelled on similar groups in Britain and elsewhere.<ref name=stevenson>{{cite web|last=Stevenson|first=Shanna|title=National League for Woman’s Service: Minute Women of Washington|url=http://www.washingtonhistory.org/research/whc/milestones/aftersuffrage/minutewomen/nlws/|accessdate=8 May 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=The National League of Women's Services|url=http://brooklynology.brooklynpubliclibrary.org/post/2010/07/29/National-League-of-Womens-Services.aspx|accessdate=8 May 2014}}</ref> The League was divided into thirteen national divisions, one of which was "Wireless and Telegraphy".<ref>{{cite book|last=Clarke|first=Ida Clyde|author-link=Ida Clyde Clarke|title=American Women and the World War|date=1918|publisher=D. Appleton and Company|location=New York; London|url=http://www.gwpda.org/wwi-www/Clarke/Clarke14.htm}}</ref> When the US entered the war in April 1917, the NLWS established training program for female wireless operators at [[Hunter College]] in New York.<ref>{{cite news|title=WOMEN GET INTO WIRELESS SERVICE; Hunter College to Graduate Two Girls Who Are Expert Operators.CLASS DOES MEN'S WORK 100 Students Taking the Course Will Be Qualified to AidIn War Work. Will Do Land Service. Appeal to Hunter College.|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F30A1EFF385F1B7A93C2A8178DD85F438185F9#|accessdate=8 May 2014|newspaper=New York Times}}</ref><ref>{{cite web | title= United States Early Radio History | author= Thomas H. White | url= https://earlyradiohistory.us/sec012.htm | accessdate= 2012-02-17 }}</ref> Although they were not strictly government employees, these female wireless operators were allowed to transmit in order to help the war effort.
==Women as broadcast radio engineers== [[File:Violet McKenzie with wireless.png|thumb|right|[[Florence Violet McKenzie]] working with the wireless radio c1922]] By 1920, the technology had evolved to the point where voice and music could be transmitted as well as Morse telegraphy, and several radio stations began to broadcast regular programs of music and news. In 1920, Eunice Randall (1898-1982), an employee of The American Radio and Research Company, or AMRAD, became an engineer and announcer for the AMRAD radio station, 1XE. Her interest in radio had begun at the age of nineteen, when she built her own amateur radio equipment and operated with the call sign 1CDP. In addition to her technical duties at 1XE, which included repairing equipment and occasionally climbing the transmitting tower, she read stories for children as "The Story Lady," and gave the police report over the air.
In 1922, the AMRAD station changed its call sign to WGI. Eunice Randall remained as engineer and assistant chief announcer until 1925, when the company went bankrupt and the station was taken off the air. However, she continued to work as an engineer and draftsman, and resumed her amateur radio activities under the call sign of W1MPP.<ref name="operators"/><ref>{{cite web | title= Remembering the Ladies-- A Salute to the Women of Early Radio | author= Donna L. Halper | url= http://www.distinguishedwomen.com/biographies/remembering.html | accessdate= 2012-02-17 }}</ref>
[[Florence Violet McKenzie|Florence Violet Mackenzie]] [[OBE]] (1890–1982), Australia's first female [[electrical engineer]], founded the [[Women's Emergency Signalling Corps]] (WESC) and trained thousands of service personnel in her [[Sydney]] signal instruction school.<ref name="DoS">{{cite web |url= http://www.dictionaryofsydney.org/entry/mckenzie_violet |title = McKenzie, Violet | author = Catherine Freyne | year = 2010 |work = Dictionary of Sydney |publisher = Dictionary of Sydney Trust |accessdate=5 January 2012}}</ref> She later corresponded with [[Albert Einstein]].<ref name="HJS">{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/rn/hindsight/stories/2009/2451146.htm |title=Hindsight – 18 January 2009 – Signals, currents, and wires: the untold story of Florence Violet McKenzie |publisher=Abc.net.au |date=2009-01-18 |accessdate=18 March 2011 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100203054054/http://www.abc.net.au/rn/hindsight/stories/2009/2451146.htm |archivedate=February 3, 2010 }}</ref>
